meta.sourceEdition: The Memoirs of Lady Hyegyong (UC Press translation)

sources.label: Principal Persons
sources.edition: The Memoirs of Lady Hyegyong (UC Press, 2013 ebook)

sourceSegments.label: Principal Persons: CHŎNG HUGYŎM
sourceSegments.excerpt: CHŎNG HUGYŎM (1750–1776). Princess Hwawan’s adopted son. He passed examinations in 1766 and wielded power while King Yŏngjo was on the throne. When Chŏngjo came to the throne in 1776, he was executed under a charge of disloyalty to Chŏngjo.

sourceSegments.label: Principal Persons: CHŎNG HWIRYANG
sourceSegments.excerpt: CHŎNG HWIRYANG (1706–1762). Chŏng Ch’idal’s uncle. He had a successful official career that included an appointment as the Minister of the Left. When Prince Sado went to P’yŏngyang, Chŏng was the Governor of P’yŏngan Province.

sourceSegments.label: Principal Persons: HONG HYŎNBO
sourceSegments.excerpt: HONG HYŎNBO (1688–1740). Lady Hyegyŏng’s paternal grandfather. He was a descendant of Princess Chŏngmyŏng, King Sŏnjo’s daughter, and had a respectable official career that included an appointment as Minister of Rites.

sourceSegments.label: Principal Persons: HONG INHAN
sourceSegments.excerpt: HONG INHAN (1722–1776). Hong Ponghan’s younger brother. After passing the civil service examination in 1753, he served in important posts. He was Minister of the Right in 1774 and Minister of the Left in 1775. He opposed Chŏngjo’s regency in 1775. Upon Chŏngjo’s accession in 1776, he was executed under charges of disloyalty to Chŏngjo.

sourceSegments.label: Principal Persons: HONG KUGYŎNG
sourceSegments.excerpt: HONG KUGYŎNG (1748–1781). Chŏngjo’s confidant in the early years of Chŏngjo’s reign. A member of another branch of the Hong family, but also a nemesis of Hong Inhan. Though he helped Chŏngjo to consolidate his power, he became too powerful. His schemes to become an affinal relative of the royal house did not succeed, and he died in banishment.

sourceSegments.label: Principal Persons: HONG NAGIM
sourceSegments.excerpt: HONG NAGIM (1741–1801). Hong Ponghan’s third son. Referred to as the third brother by Lady Hyegyŏng. He passed the civil service examination in 1769 and shortly thereafter retired to private life. In 1801, he was accused of having converted to Catholicism, and executed.

sourceSegments.label: Principal Persons: HONG NAGIN
sourceSegments.excerpt: HONG NAGIN (1730–1777). Hong Ponghan’s oldest son. Lady Hyegyŏng’s older brother. He had a successful official career.

sourceSegments.label: Principal Persons: HONG NAGYUN
sourceSegments.excerpt: HONG NAGYUN (1750–1813). Hong Ponghan’s fourth and youngest son. Referred to as the fourth brother. He never served in office.

sourceSegments.label: Principal Persons: HONG NAKSIN
sourceSegments.excerpt: HONG NAKSIN (1739–?). Hong Ponghan’s second son. Referred to as the second brother. He passed the civil service examination in 1766 but retired from office in 1770 to live in the countryside.

sourceSegments.label: Principal Persons: HONG PONGHAN
sourceSegments.excerpt: HONG PONGHAN (1713–1778). Lady Hyegyŏng’s father. With his daughter’s marriage to Crown Prince Sado and his subsequent passing of the civil service examination in 1744, he served in office for almost three decades. After Prince Sado’s death, Hong emerged as Chŏngjo’s protector. In his later years, he repeatedly came under attack for his supposed role in the Sado incident.

sourceSegments.label: Principal Persons: HONG SUYŎNG
sourceSegments.excerpt: HONG SUYŎNG (1755–?). Hong Nagin’s eldest son, thus the heir to the Hong family. The Memoir 1795 is addressed to him.

sourceSegments.label: Principal Persons: KIM CHONGSU
sourceSegments.excerpt: KIM CHONGSU (1728–1799). Related to the Hong family on his maternal side, but on bad terms with them. He worked closely with Hong Kugyŏng. When Hong Kugyŏng fell from power, he turned against him, and thus he was able to remain in office. He eventually rose to high positions, serving as Minister of the Right and Minister of the Left.

sourceSegments.label: Principal Persons: KIM HAN’GI
sourceSegments.excerpt: KIM HAN’GI (dates unknown). Kim Han’gu’s brother and ally.

sourceSegments.label: Principal Persons: KIM KWANJU
sourceSegments.excerpt: KIM KWANJU (1743–1806). Kim Kwiju’s cousin and a political ally. He was banished after Chŏngjo’s accession. During Queen Chŏngsun’s regency (1800–1804), he reached the position of Minister of the Right. But subsequently, he was banished.

sourceSegments.label: Principal Persons: KIM SIMUK
sourceSegments.excerpt: KIM SIMUK (1722–1772). Father of Queen Hyoŭi and Chŏngjo’s father-in-law. He was given the title of Lord Ch’ŏngwŏn and served in various posts.

sourceSegments.label: Principal Persons: LADY HYEGYŎNG
sourceSegments.excerpt: LADY HYEGYŎNG (1735–1815). The author of the memoirs. Hong Ponghan’s daughter. She married Prince Sado in 1744 and bore him Chŏngjo and the Princesses Ch’ŏngyŏn and Ch’ŏngsŏn.

sourceSegments.label: Principal Persons: LADY KASUN
sourceSegments.excerpt: LADY KASUN (dates unknown). King Chŏngjo’s secondary consort and King Sunjo’s mother. Unlike most secondary consorts, she was the daughter of a high-ranking official. Her father, Pak Chunwŏn, served as Minister of Justice. She was selected and brought into palace in 1787 through a formal procedure.

sourceSegments.label: Principal Persons: LORD HŬNGŬN
sourceSegments.excerpt: LORD HŬNGŬN (dates unknown). Chŏng Chaehwa. The husband of Princess Ch’ŏngsŏn and the brother-in-law of Chŏngjo. He is known as a fun-loving person who led Chŏngjo a bit astray in his adolescence and before he ascended to the throne. This event led to difficulties between Hong Ponghan and his grandson, Chŏngjo.

sourceSegments.label: Principal Persons: MADAME HONG
sourceSegments.excerpt: MADAME HONG (1746–?). Lady Hyegyŏng’s younger sister. She married Yi Pogil in 1759, but because her husband’s father was implicated in a seditious plot, she led a difficult life.

sourceSegments.label: Principal Persons: MADAME MIN
sourceSegments.excerpt: MADAME MIN (dates unknown). Hong Nagin’s wife. Born to the illustrious Min of Yŏhung family, she married Hong Nagin in 1745.

sourceSegments.label: Principal Persons: MADAME YI
sourceSegments.excerpt: MADAME YI (1713–1755). Hong Ponghan’s wife and Lady Hyegyŏng’s mother. She was the daughter of Yi Chip, who, at the time of his daughter’s marriage, was serving as Governor of Hwanghae Province.

sourceSegments.label: Principal Persons: PRINCE HYOJANG
sourceSegments.excerpt: PRINCE HYOJANG (1719–1728). Yŏngjo’s first heir apparent, but he died in his tenth year.

sourceSegments.label: Principal Persons: PRINCE SADO
sourceSegments.excerpt: PRINCE SADO (1735–1762). Yŏngjo’s son born of Lady Sŏnhŭi. Lady Hyegyŏng married him 1744. He was appointed heir apparent in 1736 and Prince-Regent in 1749. He became mad and violent. In 1762, Sado was ordered by Yŏngjo to enter a rice chest in which he died eight days later.

sourceSegments.label: Principal Persons: PRINCE ŬNŎN
sourceSegments.excerpt: PRINCE ŬNŎN (1754–1801). Prince Sado’s son by Lady Yim Sukpin. He was named In. He was accused of involvement in Catholicism and executed in one of the persecutions of Catholics.

sourceSegments.label: Principal Persons: PRINCE ŬNSIN
sourceSegments.excerpt: PRINCE ŬNSIN (1755–1771). Prince Sado’s son by Lady Yim Sukpin, and so, Ŭnŏn’s younger brother. He was named Chin. Accused of having been involved in a seditious scheme, he was banished to an island in 1771 and soon died there.

sourceSegments.label: Principal Persons: PRINCESS CH’ŎNGSŎN
sourceSegments.excerpt: PRINCESS CH’ŎNGSŎN (1756–1802). Prince Sado and Lady Hyegyŏng’s second daughter. Married Chŏng Chaehwa, known as Lord Hŭngŭn, in 1766.

sourceSegments.label: Principal Persons: PRINCESS CH’ŎNGYŎN
sourceSegments.excerpt: PRINCESS CH’ŎNGYŎN (1754–?). Prince Sado and Lady Hyegyŏng’s first daughter. She married Kim Kisŏng in 1764.

sourceSegments.label: Principal Persons: PRINCESS HWAHYŎP
sourceSegments.excerpt: PRINCESS HWAHYŎP (1733–1752). Yŏngjo’s seventh daughter, born of Lady Sŏnhŭi. She died of measles.

sourceSegments.label: Principal Persons: PRINCESS HWAWAN
sourceSegments.excerpt: PRINCESS HWAWAN (1738–?). Yŏngjo’s favorite daughter. She married Chŏng Ch’idal but was widowed young. While her father was alive, she wielded great power. She left the palace when Chŏngjo ascended the throne. In 1778, under official pressure, Chŏngjo stripped her of her royal title and the privileges associated with it and banished her to Kanghwa Island. In 1782 Chŏngjo allowed her to move to a location near the capital.

sourceSegments.label: Principal Persons: QUEEN CHŎNGSŎNG
sourceSegments.excerpt: QUEEN CHŎNGSŎNG (1692–1757). Yongjo’s first wife. Sŏ Chongje’s daughter. Estranged from her husband, she was childless.

sourceSegments.label: Principal Persons: QUEEN CHŎNGSUN
sourceSegments.excerpt: QUEEN CHŎNGSUN (1745–1805). Kim Han’gu’s daughter and Yŏngjo’s second queen. The royal wedding took place in 1759. For four years from 1800 to 1804, she was the dowager regent to the minor king, Sunjo, during which time Lady Hyegyŏng’s family suffered. Her family were archrivals of the Hong family.

sourceSegments.label: Principal Persons: QUEEN DOWAGER INWŎN
sourceSegments.excerpt: QUEEN DOWAGER INWŎN (1687–1757). Sukchong’s third queen. Kim Chusin’s daughter. Yŏngjo was said to have been devoted to this stepmother.

sourceSegments.label: Principal Persons: QUEEN HYOŬI
sourceSegments.excerpt: QUEEN HYOŬI (1753–1821). She married Chŏngjo in 1762. She was the daughter of Kim Simuk.

sourceSegments.label: The Memoir of 1795: Opening movement
sourceSegments.excerpt: From the time I came to the palace as a child, each morning and evening I exchanged letters of greeting with my parents, and many of those letters should have remained with my family.

sourceSegments.label: The Memoir of 1801: Opening movement
sourceSegments.excerpt: Princess Hwap’yŏng was Lady Sŏnhŭi’s first daughter and His Majesty loved her above all his other children.

sourceSegments.label: The Memoir of 1802: Opening movement
sourceSegments.excerpt: It has been almost sixty years since I came to the palace as a child.

sourceSegments.label: The Memoir of 1805: Opening movement
sourceSegments.excerpt: The tragedy of the imo year (1762) is unparalleled.

sourceSegments.label: Birth of Lady Hyegyŏng
sourceSegments.excerpt: I was born ... in the ... ŭlmyo year (1735).

sourceSegments.label: Hyegyŏng selected and married into the palace
sourceSegments.excerpt: ... it was I who was selected as the bride of the Crown Prince.

sourceSegments.label: Birth of Jeongjo
sourceSegments.excerpt: Prince Sado's son born of Lady Hyegyŏng in 1752.

sourceSegments.label: Deaths of Queen Chŏngsŏng and Queen Dowager Inwŏn
sourceSegments.excerpt: The Two Highnesses' passing ... left the palace empty and desolate.

sourceSegments.label: Pingae killed during Sado's violent decline
sourceSegments.excerpt: In 1761 Sado, in madness, beat her to death.

sourceSegments.label: Imo-year tragedy (death of Prince Sado)
sourceSegments.excerpt: The tragedy of the imo year (1762) is unparalleled.

sourceSegments.label: Jeongjo accedes to throne
sourceSegments.excerpt: ... succeeded to the throne in 1776 upon the death of Yŏngjo.

sourceSegments.label: Reinterment of Sado at Hyŏllyung
sourceSegments.excerpt: ... he carried out reinterment, changing the name of the tomb to Hyŏllyung Tomb.

sourceSegments.label: 1795 Hwasŏng visit and public filial ceremonies
sourceSegments.excerpt: In the spring of ŭlmyo (1795), he took me to the Prince's tomb ...

sourceSegments.label: Death of Jeongjo and accession of Sunjo
sourceSegments.excerpt: King Chŏngjo ... died in 1800.

sourceSegments.label: Execution of Hong Nagim
sourceSegments.excerpt: In 1801, he was accused of having converted to Catholicism, and executed.

sourceSegments.label: Memoir of 1802 composed for future vindication
sourceSegments.excerpt: ... I will entrust these writings to Lady Kasun ... after my death.

sourceSegments.label: Memoir of 1805 finalized
sourceSegments.excerpt: ... resisting death and weeping blood, I wrote this record.

people.biography: Princess Hwawan’s adopted son. He passed examinations in 1766 and wielded power while King Yŏngjo was on the throne. When Chŏngjo came to the throne in 1776, he was executed under a charge of disloyalty to Chŏngjo.
Chŏng Ch’idal’s uncle. He had a successful official career that included an appointment as the Minister of the Left. When Prince Sado went to P’yŏngyang, Chŏng was the Governor of P’yŏngan Province.
A country scholar. He sent memorials viciously attacking Hong Ponghan, which led to Hong’s dismissal. He was executed.
Lady Hyegyŏng’s paternal grandfather. He was a descendant of Princess Chŏngmyŏng, King Sŏnjo’s daughter, and had a respectable official career that included an appointment as Minister of Rites.

Hong Ponghan’s younger brother. After passing the civil service examination in 1753, he served in important posts. He was Minister of the Right in 1774 and Minister of the Left in 1775. He opposed Chŏngjo’s regency in 1775. Upon Chŏngjo’s accession in 1776, he was executed under charges of disloyalty to Chŏngjo.

Chŏngjo’s confidant in the early years of Chŏngjo’s reign. A member of another branch of the Hong family, but also a nemesis of Hong Inhan. Though he helped Chŏngjo to consolidate his power, he became too powerful. His schemes to become an affinal relative of the royal house did not succeed, and he died in banishment.

Hong Ponghan’s third son. Referred to as the third brother by Lady Hyegyŏng. He passed the civil service examination in 1769 and shortly thereafter retired to private life. In 1801, he was accused of having converted to Catholicism, and executed.
Hong Ponghan’s oldest son. Lady Hyegyŏng’s older brother. He had a successful official career.
Hong Ponghan’s fourth and youngest son. Referred to as the fourth brother. He never served in office.
Hong Ponghan’s second son. Referred to as the second brother. He passed the civil service examination in 1766 but retired from office in 1770 to live in the countryside.

Lady Hyegyŏng’s father. With his daughter’s marriage to Crown Prince Sado and his subsequent passing of the civil service examination in 1744, he served in office for almost three decades. After Prince Sado’s death, Hong emerged as Chŏngjo’s protector. In his later years, he repeatedly came under attack for his supposed role in the Sado incident.
Hong Nagin’s eldest son, thus the heir to the Hong family. The Memoir 1795 is addressed to him.

Related to the Hong family on his maternal side, but on bad terms with them. He worked closely with Hong Kugyŏng. When Hong Kugyŏng fell from power, he turned against him, and thus he was able to remain in office. He eventually rose to high positions, serving as Minister of the Right and Minister of the Left.
Kim Han’gu’s brother and ally.
Queen Chŏngsun’s father, thus Yŏngjo’s father-in-law. He was given the title Lord Ohŭng. The Kim family were archrivals of the Hong family.

Kim Kwiju’s cousin and a political ally. He was banished after Chŏngjo’s accession. During Queen Chŏngsun’s regency (1800–1804), he reached the position of Minister of the Right. But subsequently, he was banished.

Queen Chŏngsun’s brother. The most politically active member of the Kyŏngju Kim family, who were in contention with the Hong family. Upon Chŏngjo’s accession in 1776, he was banished to Hŭksan Island. In 1784 he was allowed to settle in Naju, where he died of illness.
Father of Queen Hyoŭi and Chŏngjo’s father-in-law. He was given the title of Lord Ch’ŏngwŏn and served in various posts.

Prince Sado’s son born of Lady Hyegyŏng in 1752. Referred to as the Grand Heir, the King, and the late King. Appointed Crown Prince in 1762 after his father’s death, he was appointed Regent in 1775 and succeeded to the throne in 1776 upon the death of Yŏngjo, his grandfather. He died in 1800.

Lady Hyegyŏng’s grandson and King Chŏngjo’s son born of Lady Kasun in 1790. Three of Lady Hyegyŏng’s memoirs, The Memoir of 1801, The Memoir of 1802, and The Memoir of 1805 were written for him. Referred to as the young King or the present King.
people.relationToHyegyong: grandson and King Chŏngjo’s son born of Lady Kasun in 1790

people.biography: Sukchong’s son born of Lady Ch’oe Sukpin in 1694. Referred to as His Majesty. Appointed heir apparent in 1721, he succeeded his brother to the throne in 1724. A brilliant but tempestuous ruler. Sado’s father.
The author of the memoirs. Hong Ponghan’s daughter. She married Prince Sado in 1744 and bore him Chŏngjo and the Princesses Ch’ŏngyŏn and Ch’ŏngsŏn.

King Chŏngjo’s secondary consort and King Sunjo’s mother. Unlike most secondary consorts, she was the daughter of a high-ranking official. Her father, Pak Chunwŏn, served as Minister of Justice. She was selected and brought into palace in 1787 through a formal procedure.

Yŏngjo’s secondary consort. She gave birth to the Princesses Hwanyŏng and Hwagil in 1753 and 1754. She was thought to have engaged in schemes to eliminate the heir apparent, Chŏngjo, and thus, upon Chŏngjo’s accession in 1776, she was executed.
Yŏngjo’s secondary consort. She bore Prince Sado and several princesses. She is reported to have urged Yŏngjo to kill Sado when Sado became very violent.

Chŏng Chaehwa. The husband of Princess Ch’ŏngsŏn and the brother-in-law of Chŏngjo. He is known as a fun-loving person who led Chŏngjo a bit astray in his adolescence and before he ascended to the throne. This event led to difficulties between Hong Ponghan and his grandson, Chŏngjo.
Chŏng Ch’idal. Princess Hwawan’s husband.
Lady Hyegyŏng’s younger sister. She married Yi Pogil in 1759, but because her husband’s father was implicated in a seditious plot, she led a difficult life.
Hong Nagin’s wife. Born to the illustrious Min of Yŏhung family, she married Hong Nagin in 1745.
Hong Ponghan’s wife and Lady Hyegyŏng’s mother. She was the daughter of Yi Chip, who, at the time of his daughter’s marriage, was serving as Governor of Hwanghae Province.

Sado’s secondary consort. Née Pak, she was given the title Kyŏngbin. She had been a lady-in-waiting to Queen Dowager Inwŏn, and so there was a taboo on Sado’s taking her in. Sado was fond of her and took her in despite the taboo and stern paternal disapproval. She bore him two children, Prince Ŭnjŏn and Princess Ch’ŏnggŭn. In 1761 Sado, in madness, beat her to death.
Yŏngjo’s first heir apparent, but he died in his tenth year.

Yŏngjo’s son born of Lady Sŏnhŭi. Lady Hyegyŏng married him 1744. He was appointed heir apparent in 1736 and Prince-Regent in 1749. He became mad and violent. In 1762, Sado was ordered by Yŏngjo to enter a rice chest in which he died eight days later.
Prince Sado’s son by Lady Yim Sukpin. He was named In. He was accused of involvement in Catholicism and executed in one of the persecutions of Catholics.

Prince Sado’s son by Lady Yim Sukpin, and so, Ŭnŏn’s younger brother. He was named Chin. Accused of having been involved in a seditious scheme, he was banished to an island in 1771 and soon died there.
Prince Sado and Lady Hyegyŏng’s second daughter. Married Chŏng Chaehwa, known as Lord Hŭngŭn, in 1766.
Prince Sado and Lady Hyegyŏng’s first daughter. She married Kim Kisŏng in 1764.
Yŏngjo’s seventh daughter, born of Lady Sŏnhŭi. She died of measles.
Yongjo’s third daughter, born of Lady Sŏnhŭi. Beloved by her father, she died in childbirth.
Yŏngjo’s second daughter, born of Lady Yi Chŏngbin. She starved herself to death upon her husband’s death.

Yŏngjo’s favorite daughter. She married Chŏng Ch’idal but was widowed young. While her father was alive, she wielded great power. She left the palace when Chŏngjo ascended the throne. In 1778, under official pressure, Chŏngjo stripped her of her royal title and the privileges associated with it and banished her to Kanghwa Island. In 1782 Chŏngjo allowed her to move to a location near the capital.
Yongjo’s first wife. Sŏ Chongje’s daughter. Estranged from her husband, she was childless.

Kim Han’gu’s daughter and Yŏngjo’s second queen. The royal wedding took place in 1759. For four years from 1800 to 1804, she was the dowager regent to the minor king, Sunjo, during which time Lady Hyegyŏng’s family suffered. Her family were archrivals of the Hong family.
Sukchong’s third queen. Kim Chusin’s daughter. Yŏngjo was said to have been devoted to this stepmother.
Prince Hyojang’s widow and the daughter of Cho Munmyŏng. She was posthumously given the title of queen in 1776 when her adopted son, Chŏngjo, ascended the throne.
She married Chŏngjo in 1762. She was the daughter of Kim Simuk.

places.name: Ch'angdŏk Palace
places.summary: Primary Joseon palace setting for many inner-court events in the memoir narrative.

places.name: Ch'anggyŏng Palace
places.summary: Frequent setting for royal residences, mourning spaces, and political tensions.

places.name: Chŏsŭng Pavilion
places.summary: Prince Sado's early residence, presented as formative in the 1805 memoir.

places.name: Hyŏllyung Tomb
places.summary: Reinterment site for Prince Sado, central to Jeongjo's filial statecraft.

places.name: Hwasŏng
places.summary: Jeongjo's monumental urban and memorial project linked to Sado's tomb.

places.name: Kop'yŏng-dong
places.summary: Hyegyong's stated birthplace in the 1795 memoir opening.

events.title: Birth of Lady Hyegyŏng
events.summary: Hyegyong records her birth at Kop'yŏng-dong, opening her life chronology.

events.title: Hyegyŏng selected and married into the palace
events.summary: Hyegyong is selected as bride of Crown Prince Sado and enters palace life.

events.title: Birth of Jeongjo
events.summary: Prince Sado and Lady Hyegyong's son is born; he later reigns as Jeongjo.

events.title: Deaths of Queen Chŏngsŏng and Queen Dowager Inwŏn
events.summary: Two key senior queens die in close succession, deepening court instability.

events.title: Pingae killed during Sado's violent decline
events.summary: Pingae, Sado's favored consort, is killed amid escalating disorder.

events.title: Imo-year tragedy (death of Prince Sado)
events.summary: Sado is ordered into the rice chest and dies; memoir tradition revolves around this rupture.

events.title: Jeongjo accedes to throne
events.summary: Following Yŏngjo's death, Jeongjo's accession reshapes factional alignments.

events.title: Reinterment of Sado at Hyŏllyung
events.summary: Jeongjo moves Sado's tomb, initiating a major filial-political project.

events.title: 1795 Hwasŏng visit and public filial ceremonies
events.summary: Jeongjo takes Hyegyong to Sado's tomb and stages large commemorative ceremonies.

events.title: Death of Jeongjo and accession of Sunjo
events.summary: Jeongjo's death creates a regency period and a crisis phase in late memoirs.

events.title: Execution of Hong Nagim
events.summary: Hyegyong's third brother is executed, central to the 1802 memoir's tone.

events.title: Memoir of 1802 composed for future vindication
events.summary: Hyegyong writes to preserve testimony for Sunjo and future redress.

events.title: Memoir of 1805 finalized
events.summary: Hyegyong's final memoir presents a full account of the 1762 catastrophe.

relationships.summary: Marriage formed the core dynastic tie between the Hong family and the royal line.
Hyegyong's son Jeongjo became central to her political and personal survival.
Late memoirs are explicitly addressed to Sunjo as dynastic testimony.
Hyegyong repeatedly frames her life through filial ties to her father.
Her mother's death becomes a major emotional and narrative turning point.
The father-son rupture drives the Imo-year catastrophe.
Lady Sŏnhŭi is a key maternal and court figure in Sado-era narrative episodes.
Jeongjo's succession is shaped by his grandfather's court and decisions.
Jeongjo's queen from the Kim lineage appears in succession and court context.
Lady Kasun bears Sunjo and becomes central in late-dynastic continuity.
Sunjo's maternal line becomes key during minority rule and regency politics.
Queen Chŏngsun ruled as dowager regent during Sunjo's minority.
Kim Kwiju's factional activity is tied to Queen Chŏngsun's family network.
Hugyŏm's power rose through Princess Hwawan's position at court.
Hong Nagim was Hyegyong's third brother and central in late memoir politics.
Hong Nagim's execution in 1801 is a major trauma in late memoirs.
Hyegyong frames the regency years as a period of intensified persecution.
Hong Ponghan appears as a protector of Jeongjo after the 1762 crisis.
Hong Kugyŏng consolidated early Jeongjo authority before his own fall.
Kim Chongsu collaborated with and later turned against Hong Kugyŏng.
The Kim-Hong rivalry is a recurrent political axis in the memoirs.

claims.value: Princess Hwawan’s adopted son. He passed examinations in 1766 and wielded power while King Yŏngjo was on the throne. When Chŏngjo came to the throne in 1776, he was executed under a charge of disloyalty to Chŏngjo.

Though he helped Chŏngjo to consolidate his power, he became too powerful. His schemes to become an affinal relative of the royal house did not succeed, and he died in banishment.

Hong Ponghan’s third son. Referred to as the third brother by Lady Hyegyŏng. He passed the civil service examination in 1769 and shortly thereafter retired to private life. In 1801, he was accused of having converted to Catholicism, and executed.
Hong Ponghan’s oldest son. Lady Hyegyŏng’s older brother. He had a successful official career.
Hong Ponghan’s fourth and youngest son. Referred to as the fourth brother. He never served in office.
Hong Ponghan’s second son. Referred to as the second brother. He passed the civil service examination in 1766 but retired from office in 1770 to live in the countryside.

Lady Hyegyŏng’s father. With his daughter’s marriage to Crown Prince Sado and his subsequent passing of the civil service examination in 1744, he served in office for almost three decades. After Prince Sado’s death, Hong emerged as Chŏngjo’s protector. In his later years, he repeatedly came under attack for his supposed role in the Sado incident.

claims.notes: Seed office term for timeline exploration.

claims.value: Hong Nagin’s eldest son, thus the heir to the Hong family. The Memoir 1795 is addressed to him.

Related to the Hong family on his maternal side, but on bad terms with them. He worked closely with Hong Kugyŏng. When Hong Kugyŏng fell from power, he turned against him, and thus he was able to remain in office. He eventually rose to high positions, serving as Minister of the Right and Minister of the Left.
Kim Han’gu’s brother and ally.
Queen Chŏngsun’s father, thus Yŏngjo’s father-in-law. He was given the title Lord Ohŭng. The Kim family were archrivals of the Hong family.

Kim Kwiju’s cousin and a political ally. He was banished after Chŏngjo’s accession. During Queen Chŏngsun’s regency (1800–1804), he reached the position of Minister of the Right. But subsequently, he was banished.

Queen Chŏngsun’s brother. The most politically active member of the Kyŏngju Kim family, who were in contention with the Hong family. Upon Chŏngjo’s accession in 1776, he was banished to Hŭksan Island. In 1784 he was allowed to settle in Naju, where he died of illness.
Father of Queen Hyoŭi and Chŏngjo’s father-in-law. He was given the title of Lord Ch’ŏngwŏn and served in various posts.

Prince Sado’s son born of Lady Hyegyŏng in 1752. Referred to as the Grand Heir, the King, and the late King. Appointed Crown Prince in 1762 after his father’s death, he was appointed Regent in 1775 and succeeded to the throne in 1776 upon the death of Yŏngjo, his grandfather. He died in 1800.

claims.notes: Seed office term for timeline exploration.
Seed office term for timeline exploration.
Seed office term for timeline exploration.

claims.value: Lady Hyegyŏng’s grandson and King Chŏngjo’s son born of Lady Kasun in 1790. Three of Lady Hyegyŏng’s memoirs, The Memoir of 1801, The Memoir of 1802, and The Memoir of 1805 were written for him. Referred to as the young King or the present King.

claims.notes: Seed office term for timeline exploration.

claims.value: Sukchong’s son born of Lady Ch’oe Sukpin in 1694. Referred to as His Majesty. Appointed heir apparent in 1721, he succeeded his brother to the throne in 1724. A brilliant but tempestuous ruler. Sado’s father.

claims.notes: Seed office term for timeline exploration.

claims.value: The author of the memoirs. Hong Ponghan’s daughter. She married Prince Sado in 1744 and bore him Chŏngjo and the Princesses Ch’ŏngyŏn and Ch’ŏngsŏn.

claims.notes: Seed office term for timeline exploration.

claims.value: King Chŏngjo’s secondary consort and King Sunjo’s mother. Unlike most secondary consorts, she was the daughter of a high-ranking official. Her father, Pak Chunwŏn, served as Minister of Justice. She was selected and brought into palace in 1787 through a formal procedure.

Yŏngjo’s secondary consort. She gave birth to the Princesses Hwanyŏng and Hwagil in 1753 and 1754. She was thought to have engaged in schemes to eliminate the heir apparent, Chŏngjo, and thus, upon Chŏngjo’s accession in 1776, she was executed.
Yŏngjo’s secondary consort. She bore Prince Sado and several princesses. She is reported to have urged Yŏngjo to kill Sado when Sado became very violent.

Chŏng Chaehwa. The husband of Princess Ch’ŏngsŏn and the brother-in-law of Chŏngjo. He is known as a fun-loving person who led Chŏngjo a bit astray in his adolescence and before he ascended to the throne. This event led to difficulties between Hong Ponghan and his grandson, Chŏngjo.
Chŏng Ch’idal. Princess Hwawan’s husband.
Lady Hyegyŏng’s younger sister. She married Yi Pogil in 1759, but because her husband’s father was implicated in a seditious plot, she led a difficult life.
Hong Nagin’s wife. Born to the illustrious Min of Yŏhung family, she married Hong Nagin in 1745.
Hong Ponghan’s wife and Lady Hyegyŏng’s mother. She was the daughter of Yi Chip, who, at the time of his daughter’s marriage, was serving as Governor of Hwanghae Province.

Sado’s secondary consort. Née Pak, she was given the title Kyŏngbin. She had been a lady-in-waiting to Queen Dowager Inwŏn, and so there was a taboo on Sado’s taking her in. Sado was fond of her and took her in despite the taboo and stern paternal disapproval. She bore him two children, Prince Ŭnjŏn and Princess Ch’ŏnggŭn. In 1761 Sado, in madness, beat her to death.
Yŏngjo’s first heir apparent, but he died in his tenth year.

Yŏngjo’s son born of Lady Sŏnhŭi. Lady Hyegyŏng married him 1744. He was appointed heir apparent in 1736 and Prince-Regent in 1749. He became mad and violent. In 1762, Sado was ordered by Yŏngjo to enter a rice chest in which he died eight days later.

claims.notes: Seed office term for timeline exploration.
Seed office term for timeline exploration.

claims.value: Prince Sado’s son by Lady Yim Sukpin. He was named In. He was accused of involvement in Catholicism and executed in one of the persecutions of Catholics.

Prince Sado’s son by Lady Yim Sukpin, and so, Ŭnŏn’s younger brother. He was named Chin. Accused of having been involved in a seditious scheme, he was banished to an island in 1771 and soon died there.
Prince Sado and Lady Hyegyŏng’s second daughter. Married Chŏng Chaehwa, known as Lord Hŭngŭn, in 1766.
Prince Sado and Lady Hyegyŏng’s first daughter. She married Kim Kisŏng in 1764.
Yŏngjo’s seventh daughter, born of Lady Sŏnhŭi. She died of measles.
Yongjo’s third daughter, born of Lady Sŏnhŭi. Beloved by her father, she died in childbirth.
Yŏngjo’s second daughter, born of Lady Yi Chŏngbin. She starved herself to death upon her husband’s death.

Yŏngjo’s favorite daughter. She married Chŏng Ch’idal but was widowed young. While her father was alive, she wielded great power. She left the palace when Chŏngjo ascended the throne. In 1778, under official pressure, Chŏngjo stripped her of her royal title and the privileges associated with it and banished her to Kanghwa Island. In 1782 Chŏngjo allowed her to move to a location near the capital.
Yongjo’s first wife. Sŏ Chongje’s daughter. Estranged from her husband, she was childless.

Kim Han’gu’s daughter and Yŏngjo’s second queen. The royal wedding took place in 1759. For four years from 1800 to 1804, she was the dowager regent to the minor king, Sunjo, during which time Lady Hyegyŏng’s family suffered. Her family were archrivals of the Hong family.

claims.notes: Seed office term for timeline exploration.
Seed office term for timeline exploration.

claims.value: Sukchong’s third queen. Kim Chusin’s daughter. Yŏngjo was said to have been devoted to this stepmother.
Prince Hyojang’s widow and the daughter of Cho Munmyŏng. She was posthumously given the title of queen in 1776 when her adopted son, Chŏngjo, ascended the throne.
She married Chŏngjo in 1762. She was the daughter of Kim Simuk.
Marriage formed the core dynastic tie between the Hong family and the royal line.

claims.value: Hyegyong records her birth at Kop'yŏng-dong, opening her life chronology.
Hyegyong is selected as bride of Crown Prince Sado and enters palace life.
Prince Sado and Lady Hyegyong's son is born; he later reigns as Jeongjo.
Two key senior queens die in close succession, deepening court instability.
Pingae, Sado's favored consort, is killed amid escalating disorder.
Sado is ordered into the rice chest and dies; memoir tradition revolves around this rupture.
Following Yŏngjo's death, Jeongjo's accession reshapes factional alignments.
Jeongjo moves Sado's tomb, initiating a major filial-political project.
Jeongjo takes Hyegyong to Sado's tomb and stages large commemorative ceremonies.
Jeongjo's death creates a regency period and a crisis phase in late memoirs.
Hyegyong's third brother is executed, central to the 1802 memoir's tone.
Hyegyong writes to preserve testimony for Sunjo and future redress.
Hyegyong's final memoir presents a full account of the 1762 catastrophe.
